captions.text:
What it do yo? This here your boy
Doc Sweets and today we gettin savage with
Brave New World by Aldous Huxley.
It’s the year 632 AF and most o’ civilization

is part of one hood
called the World State. Up in here, technology

makin it so that humans pop off assembly lines
and be brainwashed to value nothin but what

the government tells em- constant happiness,
consumption, and bangin group orgies. Whoo-wee!

And if you still ain’t feelin fly,
just throw back a lil’ soma and you get
so iced out that you aint got no worries.

So some high class pusher named
Bernard Marx start thinkin that, unlike the

rest of them soma- slammin zombies, he a trill-ass
individual who curious bout what life on the
outside be like.

So Bernard hollers at some choice hunny named
Lenina and axe if she wanna roll with him

to the Savage
reservation where peeps be livin old school.

Lenina holla back, but she actin spicious
bout this playa since he don’t like to pop
pillz and get dirty like she do.

When Bernard and Lenina land at the
Savage Reservation, they peep some gnarly

beezy named Linda and her boy John- who be
called ‘The Savage.’

Even though John and Linda been
livin the low life, Linda schooled John how
to read, making him a top shelf savage.

After Bernard takes John back to
London, John admits to Lenina that he got

mad love for her, but dis hoochie cayn’t
even understand what that means. Instead,

she get but- ass naked and try to get freaky
wit him. But my boy John wants somethin with

meaning; so instead of tappin dat ass, he
pimp slaps her and sends her packin.

Then John’s mama bites the big one
up in the hospital and John completely loses

his sh**. So the Five-O bust in and sling
him and Bernard in front of some big bird

playa named Mustapha Mond. Mond exiles Bernard,
but makes John stay cuz he want “the experiment”
to go on.

Fed up wit the system, John
secludes himself in a lighthouse when one

day some snitch gets all up in his bidness
and peeps John whipping himself, making him
a media sensation.

Later, when a big ass crowd forms
outside his crib with Lenina in tow, John

calls her a skank and starts layin a whoop
on her. Errybody gets so riled up at the sight

that they start poppin soma screamin “Orgy
Porgy” and gettin they freak on. Even Johnny
boy joins in!

Next day John wakes up and realizes
they ain’t nothing he can do to fight the
civilized world he imprisoned in.

So our boy takes the only escape
left and hangs himself. Whew.

Welcome to the Brave New World, son. If you
wanna roll with the

World State crew, you gotta drop yo beliefs
and adopt a whole jam called Fordism. Instead

of giving up worldly possessions for a heaven
in the sky, get ready for a soma- soaked paradise

now. All you gotta do is take all dat art,
science, history, and religion- and kiss it
goodbye, play boy.

My mayne Karl Marx once said that
“religion is the opiate of da masses”.

But Huxley gone and flipped that idea on its
head and made Opium, AKA Soma, the people’s

religion. And this sh** right here is so dank
that it also offers hope, consolation, and

reassurance just like religion, cept better-
cuz you ain’t even gotta do nuthin. Just

like Mustapha Mond say, Soma is “Christianity
without tears.”

Now open up yo ears and soak this
game up, B. In a place like the World State

where the motto is “COMMUNITY, IDENTITY,
AND STABILITY,” they aint nuthin mo dangerous
than a G flying solo.

Cuz when you on your own, you ain’t
got nobody to put your strongest emotions

in check. With all yo love directed at only
one thing, you end up unstable, miserable

and wantin totake yoslf out of the game for
good. Naw mean? That’s why the world state

throwin all those swanky sex-parties, so you
can get all dat excess emotion out on the
reg.

Don’t believe me? Just look how
unstable Johnny boy be when he on the reservation-

he even shanks one of his mama’s lovers!
And it don’t get no better in the civilized

world. When Lenina’s standing butt naked
in front of him, he roughs her up, calls her

a ho, and threatens to waste her ass! Maybe
there’s a good reason they call him the
savage.

And with all that excessive emotion
building up, it’s no wonder that this fool

ices himself. Looks like Mustapha Mond’s
experiment went exactly as he expected.

Hey thanks for keepin it real wit
Thug Notes. Hit that subscribe button and
catch you next week.

title: Brave New World - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
I like most of the Thug Notes, as they are suprisingly spot on, considering 
their shortness, but this could have driven home the main point better: In 
the dialogue with Mustafah, he admits, that there is no progress, no 
meaning and nothing BUT happiness. This straight hedonism not only is sad 
and inacceptable for everyone NOT caught up in that system, but also 
devalues happiness as such, because there´s nothing to contrast it with.﻿
comments.author: Nyars Channel

comments.text:
From what i've read so far (about to start chapter 4), I can easliy see 
similarities between our world and Huxleys. The way people are fear 
mongered by a threat that is presented to them by their government. In our 
case that would be terrorism. Our media has a way of showing all terrorists 
as anyone that doesn't have white skin, conditioning people to relate brown 
skin to danger. As a result it could mean people are less likely to protest 
against police brutality towards brown people (which is a HUGE issue right 
now in America). Maybe becoming racist or not isn't purely in the hands of 
the individual, but in their influence to conditioning.
Just a thought, love from Scotland x﻿

comments.text:
A question for everyone:
Which novel, in your opinion, is closer to the possible dystopian trend 
we're on? *1984* or *Brave New World*?
Remember, it's not about which is more scary, immoral, or even 
psychologically impacting.
The question is about which is closer to the trend humanity is on, scarier 
or not.﻿
comments.author: Victor Conway

comments.text:
I guess it depends if you believe in morals/ethics as a abstract or 
subjective concepts.
comments.author: shaun Brown

comments.text:
Well "utopia" is a matter of interpretation. INGSOC and the Controller 
Council both have their vision of what a utopia is. The Controllers believe 
a utopia is a global society without war, hunger, poverty, 
inflation/deflation, population over/undergrowth, and societal conflict. 
INGSOC believes that a utopia is basically a society with a government that 
is impossible to overthrow. They hope to achieve that with a society 
completely without crime, which they hope to achieve by removing an 
individual's ability to even think of committing a crime, all their 
horrific methods follow after that principle. 

The difference between *Brave New World* and *1984* is that while *1984* is 
in the middle of achieving their perfect vision, *Brave New World* is at a 
time centuries after that achievement was already made. Nonetheless, *1984* 
makes up for the reader's illusion that a thoughtcrime-free world could be 
stopped  before it comes about by making Oceania out to be a much darker, 
crueler, nihilistic world where the impending future of the Party's 
ultimate victory appearing inevitable, even if it's 64 years away from 
happening yet.
comments.author: Victor Conway

comments.text:
what does it tell you when a book is written as a dystopia and a later 
society starts seeing it as a utopia. Sounds like the control is closer 
than you think

comments.text:
Definitely brave new world. Both are applicable I guess. But I feel like 
the world is going more towards distraction based life (movies,pop 
culture,prescription drugs,music). All of these things present day, for the 
most part have no substance, and serve the purpose of distracting people 
from the harsh reality of life. Which is what brave new world is all about. 
But you can definitely make a case for the survaliance state. But you have 
to dig a little deeper in order to uncover those truths
comments.author: huckmart 99

comments.text:
Brave New World most definitely. Orwell's 1984 has the idea that the 
dystopian future will be a result of a brutal government regime and 
propaganda, which is something we see today but definitely not to the 
extent Orwell saw it as. Most people pick this one as the inevitable future 
because its exciting and sexy. However, I think that Brave New World is 
more like the world we see today. In Brave New World the government doesn't 
need to be a brutal dictatorship because the people already fall in line or 
are too distracted to see whats happening. Soma represents the massive 
problem we have with pharmacy companies pushing doctors to prescribe 
medicine when it might not be needed, a large portion of the western world 
is sedated with some kind of mood changing drug. Feelies represent the 
media which distracts people and makes them feel better. Its easier to see 
what the Kardashians are doing than it is to recognize that you live in a 
sick society. Lastly, the ritual orgies represent the societal pressures 
that are exerted on all of us. There is this idea that you shouldn't be 
different, that you shouldn't rock the boat.

We don't need to be afraid of Big Brother because most people are going to 
be too distracted to even realize he is already there.

Edit: That being said I think 1984 is a better book.
comments.author: 18807BB

comments.text:
There are some troubling factual errors in this review: Bernard didn't get 
exiled to an island, Helmholtz did.  Bernard cried like a baby at 
Mustapha's feet, got Soma'd, and sent to his room. Also, Lenina did not 
come to the lighthouse, John may have thought it was her but the book only 
identifies this person as a "young woman." Otherwise it is a okay review of 
a great book. ﻿
comments.author: Raymon Granillo

comments.text:
Actually, Bernard did get exiled to the island. He was just given to soma 
to calm down, before being sent to the island. And it has been confirmed 
that Lenina came to the light house. The reader is supposed to assume that 
the "young woman" is Lenina even though her name is never mentioned.
comments.author: Garima Gupta

comments.text:
Both Bernard AND Helmholtz are sent to an island. At least that's what the

comments.author: Taylor Foulkrod

comments.text:
+ShyProdigy I understand completely what you were saying; I just figured 
the question flipped a little would be fun.

I don't pretend to care about purpose one way or another. It's like god, it 
would be nice if it were real, but it's not needed for the necessities of 
living to be as it is.
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+fmlAllthetime I was addressing the claim that humankind has no reason to 
live without purpose. From my perspective, the notion of purpose is 
arbitrary, which is what I was trying to get across. Maybe nothing really 
has a reason or a point, but that doesn't mean that while we're here we 
have to experience an emotional, sensory, philosophical limbo.

The way I see it, people can choose what matters to them and why, but in 
the end there's no special meaning, so everything's arbitrary in the grand 
scheme of things. But if that's the case, then what's to stop us from 
taking matters into our own hands?

I really like that question, by the way :)
comments.author: ShyProdigy

comments.text:
+ShyProdigy If it's irrelevant why it matters or not, why even ask the 
question in the first place?
comments.author: fmlAllthetime

comments.text:
+yiXal namespolicysucks If you are against SSRI drugs I can understand, but 
in extreme cases they are needed... and I would note to be damn careful how 
long you remain on them. There are other treatments coming out now that 
involve magnetic stimulation, called Transmagnetic Stimulation Treatment or 
TMS therapy (the side effects appear minimal for now, but it is another new 
treatment). You're right that if you can manage without the damn drugs you 
will be better off, but if someone is hallucinating I'd say you're better 
off on the drug temporarily until the mania goes away; then get the hell 
off them asap.

Marijuana is just as damaging as SSRIs though and can destroy your dopamine 
nervous system... otherwise do things the old-fashion way... exorcise and 
meditation

comments.text:
I think Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World" is much closer to the social 
trajectory we are actually on than George Orwell's "1984" or "Animal Farm" 
are, although aspects of these dystopian texts, (and others like C. S. 
Lewis's "That Hideous Strength" and Ayn Rand's "Atlas Shrugged") do often 
portray the working out of important tendencies in society in a very 
powerful and relevant way. "Brave New World" in particular is a text which 
gives us a depiction of the sort of people (if these sorts of characters in 
the strictly literary sense can even be called "people") who I find that I 
actually meet, which is something these others don't manage to do, while 
being open to multiple interpretations. The reader is left to decide for 
themselves, "What's wrong with this picture?" As such, thinking Huxley was 
basically right in predicting a culture with all possibility for real 
contemplation or thought buried beneath an inhuman avalanche of sex, drugs 
and insipid pop music does not make one a "Huxleyist" as it does not imply 
that one subscribes to Huxley's solutions to the problem or his non-fiction 
analysis of the problem in various non-fiction essays etc.﻿
comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
+Jonmad17 AFAIK Orwell's experience with left wing authoritarianism came 
from being on the receiving end of Stalinist backstabbing in the Spanish 
Civil-War.

Orwell signed up and served as a militia man as part of the communist POUM 
which was later declared by Stalinist propagandists as "fascist 
sympathizers" and then suppressed. The reason being presumably because the 
POUM as a group supported Trotsky and the Stalinist's wanted total control 
over the areas of Spain that the left had liberated up to that point.
comments.author: Franticalmagic

comments.text:
Truthfully, of all those books, only Brave New World is intended to 
critique the "future" the others are all using the future to talk about the 
present they were written in. 

Government control of information and thinking was nothing new when 1984 
was written. Orwell was talking about Stalin-ism, which he saw creeping 
into British politics and news. Same goes for Animal Farm. 

And by Ayn Rand's own admission, the purpose of her fiction was to provide 
Capitalist propaganda, not projecting a possible future.

Huxley was the only one that actually envisioned a future world based on 
the predominant ethics of the time, that of the assembly line. Everything 
is that factory, assembly line ethical structure. That why even birth is 
mechanical in that world.

But the real tip off that Huxley is actually considering the future, is 
John the savage. John represents tumultuous human emotion, which has no 
place on the assembly line.  What does the future hold for human 
experience? That's what Huxley is asking. And his answer: Nothing good.
comments.author: The Count Jackula Show

comments.text:
+chronotriggerfan uh ... I love Chrono Trigger, but it sounds like you've 
totally gone off the deep end with your conspiracy theory there 
chronotriggerfan. I'm talking about trends in how people in general think 
in a societal context, but you seem to be talking about some kind of 
conscious political conspiracy plot that's somehow powerful enough to be 
pulling the strings behind the way people think (or don't think, as the 
case may be) and that's not even where I was going with this at all. I 
don't think that's how it works. People don't need conspirators 
manipulating them in order to get dumber.
comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
You're absolutely right, but it's important to bear in mind that Huxley 
isn't a prophet of the technocratic/cybernetic/eugenic agenda, he's an 
active part of it. The Huxley family had been inbreeding with the Galtons 
and Wedgewoods for decades before Huxley's supposed revelations. When we 
ultimately consider Huxley's co-founding of the Esalen Institute, which has 
now been verified by FOIA requests and diligent research as an MKULTRA 
subproject, we can see that Brave New World and Huxley's "Ultimate 
Revolution" is far more akin to slick predictive programming than keen 
political conjecture.
comments.author: chronotriggerfan

comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
I hate the cliché that Orwell's dystopian vision was somehow less 
applicable to reality than Huxley's. Orwell was spot-on when it came to 
20th century left-wing totalitarianism; so much so that Czeslaw Milosz 
wrote about how amazed they (those secretly passing around 1984 in Russia) 
were to find out that Orwell had never visited the country or lived under 
Communist rule. 

Both of their visions came true, just not concurrently.

comments.text:
+Joe Johnson "sounds like Gautama's 'Middle Path' to enlightenment and 
peace"

You can find out more about it in Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics and 
Eudimonian ethics!

"Utilitarian ethics by definition sacrifice the individual for the 
whole...do you agree?"

Of course. Utilitarianism has a hard time with reconciling individual 
rights with maximum happiness. Most of the time, Utilitarians claim human 
beings have no rights because  they focus too much on our often destructive 
behavior, which would be our wanton desire to use coercion, murder and 
violence to obtain what we desire, and believe we ought to have a despotism 
to "correct" our behavior.

"Another writer. Dean Koontz, was appalled by the implications of those 
type of ethics and had a character who embraced them as a way to 
rationalize evil. The book was 'One Door Away from Heaven' I think"

I might have to check it out. Thanks!

sounds like Gautama's 'Middle Path' to enlightenment and peace
----

comments.author: Joe Johnson

comments.text:
+Joe Johnson Your welcome!To be specific, utilitarianism is about 
maximizing the greatest happiness for the greatest amount of people and the 
overall minimization of suffering for the greatest amount of people. So 
yes, your assertion is correct. I am saying that Utilitarianism is the main 
driving force behind the repressive gov't in BNW.

And that speech Mond has with The Savage is a utilitarian form of thinking. 
Not to mention when Mond expresses the society's views towards other forms 
of knowledge, such as incorrectly making statements about philosophy being 
a branch of religion (which it is not) which is what the new atheist 
movement's thoughts towards other sources of knowledge; they are useless 
and only science is the only source of knowledge.

Actually happiness and individuality can go together. That is if happiness 
is taken in moderation. For instance if one were to pursue intellectual 
happiness such as reading fine literature such as Shakespeare or writing a 
poem, both of which Huxley emphasized the importance of in the book. The 
kind of happiness that the World State practices is one of hedonistic 
happiness, or what Aristotle called pleasure or self-indulgence.

Another point Huxley also emphasized the kind of loneliness that John the 
Savage experiences when he goes into self-exile after his experiences with 
the Native American peoples and the World State, giving need for community. 
Not having other intellectual friends like Helmholtz Watson or Bernard Marx 
around is lonesome for the Savage and it's worse when the crowd of 
hedonists surround him making him feel more alone and further isolated. All 
he really has is just his traditions.

Now to look at BNW from a virtue ethicist point of view, or as Aristotle 
would see it, it is best for the individual to take moderation in 
happiness, for too much leads to self-indulgence or pleasure and less leads 
to sorrow. Hence, the utilitarian way is quite irrational and turns 
individuals to nothing more than numbers. Anyhow hope this give more food 
for thought! Cheers!
comments.author: CosmoShidan

comments.text:
+CosmoShidan well, if I'm following you right, 'utilitarianism' is the 
justification for utter government control in BNW.  That seems to be the 
thread Huxley is actually pulling at, that happiness and 
freedom/full-fledged humanity don't necessarily go together, and perhaps 
also that pleasure is not happiness. [many of the characters seem to 
experience ennui, like something is missing from their pleasurable lives, 
even if they don't know what it is{hence the soma/drug abuse thing]

so yeah, I can see your point as an under-lying theme or what Huxley is 
exploring, extrapolating utilitarianism to the nines. But when I said the 
book was 'about the crushing of individuality', well, that IS what the 
story is about: we even start out in a lab where not random chance or 'God' 
decides if a baby is smart or stupid, but government-controlled lab 
technicians. Individuality is discouraged to the point where all close 
relationships that might define an individual are discouraged, individual 
beliefs vis-a-vis 'God' are kiboshed, sleep programming, etc etc

the idea behind the crushing of individuality seems to be that it's all for 
the greatest amount of happiness for the most people, and i can agree that 
that is the rationale for BNW's repressive government[it's pretty much 
spelled out by Mond toward the end]. 

good stuff. Thank you for giving me something to think about
comments.author: Joe Johnson

comments.text:
+Joe Johnson I would argue that BNW is closer in theme to "We" by Yevgeny 
Zamyatin, as both are critiques of the philosophy Utilitarianism; more so 
than just about gov't oppression over individuals as 1984 is about. Insofar 
as both books criticize one of the main point of Utilitarianism, "the 
greatest happiness for the greatest amount", they are both about freedom vs 
pleasure, whereas 1984 is really just a critique of the Soviet Union. Also, 
the way that Mustapha Mond talks about "science, machinery and happiness" 
as the only source of knowledge and stability vs art, philosophy and 
progression as a source to stability and knowledge is much like what is 
going on with the "New Atheist" movement, and where our society is headed 
and why the state is resorting to oppression...  It's the bug known as 
Utilitarianism that is responsible.
comments.author: CosmoShidan

comments.text:
You are right. and the conclusions are off too-th point of the book was to 
show how dehumanized civilization can be, if developed according to wrong 
principles. Mustafa says this himself-the world stopped developing, poeple 
are unable to function without drugs, and you cant us your intelect. Savage 
kills himself, because he cannot adopt to unrasonable world of dehumanized 
civilization, that in reality is anthithesis of civilization. The fact is 
that civilization-is savage, and The Savage-is civilized. Huxley not only 
flipped Marx quotation, he flipped everything and put it on its head. 
Byotch.

comments.author: LordKristivas

comments.text:
I didn't get this analysis either, but the other ones were pretty sharp

BNW is a 'dystopia novel' where the dystopia is actually 
pleasant...pleasure and satisfaction are the chains the government uses 
instead of brutal repression[like '1984']

both are about the crushing of individuality, and points out that 
individualism and government authority go together like beer and chocolate 
syrup

there's also a 'yin/yang' point in there about needing pain to appreciate 
pleasure, hardship to appreciate success, etc. i think Huxley takes a dim 
view of the vapid pleasure-seeking society he creates, where the government 
controls even conception

if anything, BNW is more repressive and monstrous than the dystopia in 
1984[albeit much more pleasant for its subjects]...a free space can be in 
your mind in 1984 if you're careful not to show it, but in BNW, you don't 
even get that--you are bred and programmed from conception to adulthood not 
be able to think for yourself, and too drowned in pleasures to even feel 
that loss
comments.author: Joe Johnson

comments.text:
Are you saying that this is a Dystopian or a Utopian society? Great analyis 
- it leaves the book open for interpretation.

Here is my interpretation: Even though it goes exactly according to what 
Mustapha Mond expected, it was terrible that John the Savage kills himself. 
It is fundamentally wrong to think that your own sons suicide is acceptable 
and "according to expectations!" I think that was the ultimate point of the 
book. True living does require suffering and death, but it is not the point 
of living.

Jesus said: I am the way the truth and the life. No one comes to the Father 
except through Me. John 14:6

I loved the video! Keep up the great work!﻿

comments.text:
Brave New World is open to many interpretations, but I think one that 
stands out is that it seems to be saying that at least some difficulty, 
challenge, unhappiness and opposition is necessary for a life that is truly 
human. A child that is always given everything they want and is never told 
"No" is spoiled into a horrible monster. Huxley explores an entire society 
of people so spoiled they've become subhuman.﻿
comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
+mclovinakapascal Thank you. It's hard not to get frustrated when someone 
continues telling you that you're sub-human for not preferring a society 
founded on choice over a society founded on merit and legitimate happiness.
comments.author: PrrrromotionGiven

comments.text:
+AsiagoAssassin You fail to realize that most people don't apply this to 
reality's rules, only to the rules that the book assumes. In this universe 
there is a strict caste system, something not many people in any part of 
our world would take (in the modern age) when applied to them but in the 
terms of the book it works, especially within the basis of a strict 
meritocracy, (which starts at conception and finishes at birth.) It depends 
how on how you approach and discuss the book, as fiction or as allegory. 
For example, star wars sounds like a cool universe to live in but is much 
different when realistically thinking about living as a citizen in the 
universe.
 And ironically, a lot of people debating against the plausibility of BNW 
actually being a utopia are displaying ignorance in the form of 
narrow-mindedness by denouncing people who find it attractive as 
"sub-human". Dogma and demonizing isn't exactly empathetic and/or 
enlightened.
comments.author: mclovinakapascal

comments.text:
+Benjamin McLean The first few chapters describing the systematic way they 
treated life was one of the most horrifying descriptions I've ever read. 
One of the best beginnings to a story ever; it was immediate impact and 
told you exactly what the story was going to be like. This hideous 
mechanized society with the facade of happiness and bliss plastered over it.

I argue it's a utopia-dystopia novel because the society it presents is 
full of what the majority of human beings want, ignorance to the world 
around them. The people who argue that it's not much of a dystopian novel 
prove Huxley's point perfectly; the reader themselves believe it is an 
alright society. I also like that if you're not partaking in the social 
structure around you, you get exiled to a place where other individuals 
have free reign to govern themselves. The people believe they're in a 
utopia, but the thin facade easily fades away if you're an outsider.
comments.author: AsiagoAssassin

comments.text: EXACTLY.....
comments.author: Lila Christina Polutta

comments.text:
+mclovinakapascal "Giving up your "freedoms" to assure the happiness of 
others?" Other whats? Other people? But the characters in Brave New World 
aren't human beings anymore. They don't count as other people. They're 
mindless Pavlovian robots.

"The most they lose is social and career mobility" -- No. Medieval man 
didn't have those things, but was still human. In contrast, Brave New World 
characters aren't human.

"everyone is happy" -- More like every thing, not everyone, because they're 
no longer human beings.

"real love isn't disney-esque "pure" love." -- Real love is the willingness 
to lay down one's life for one's friends -- something Brave New World 
characters can't even comprehend.

"It's when someone fufills your needs and desires so well/much that you 
integrate them into your life until a point that you too lose when they are 
not happy or well, or fufilled." -- Brave New World characters don't have 
that. Have you actually read the book or are you just going off Thug Notes 
humorous summary?

"who ... cares about that anyways when the equivalent of church is orgies 
in BNW." -- That's not really an equivalent of church, it's a replacement 
for church and it represents how there is no moment for quiet reflection, 
no self-examination, no thought in the lives of these subhuman things that 
are left after people have gone extinct.
comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
+mclovinakapascal  I agree with Benjamin.  It is our free will and 
individualistic thinking that makes us human.
comments.author: Lila Christina Polutta

comments.text:

others? You're right! That's nothing at all like compassion and empathy. 
Fucking dumbass. The most they lose is social and career mobility, which no 
one gives a fuck about because everyone is happy and fufilled with their 
jobs and lives, and love. And drop the white knight act for a moment, real 
love isn't disney-esque "pure" love. It's when someone fufills your needs 
and desires so well/much that you integrate them into your life until a 
point that you too lose when they are not happy or well, or fufilled.  Oh 
and religion, but who the fuck cares about that anyways when the equivalent 
of church is orgies in BNW.

comments.text:
+Alvin F I don't think it being a shock had anything to do with John's 
rejection of modern society in the long run. John's rejection of modern 
society was based on principles, although they were principles he could not 
name, because even the words to name his despair had been stolen from his 
generation. That's why he obsesses over Shakespeare so much. It's the 
closest he gets to that lost understanding of how real people live.
comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
+Benjamin McLean We evolved to have compassion, because it was beneficial 
for us to work together and helped us survive and procreate, this is simply 
humans changing the game by themselves. And frankly, I expected more

literature. You don't have to agree with me but we can see eye to eye on 
some matters. Maybe in the end it's you who's lacking empathy?

"Brave New World is open to many interpretations..." Apparently not, 
according to you, the all knowing.
comments.author: mclovinakapascal

comments.text:

It's also about the dehumanization of putting your own pleasure first in

comments.text:

BNW is that it eschews empathy and is run on a hard caste system.
comments.author: chris helms

comments.text:
+mclovinakapascal No, fool. BMW is scary to us because we are human and you

comments.author: Benjamin McLean

comments.text:
+chris helms It's kind of hard to knock Utilitarianism when everything in 
the book is in order, for the most part. Everyone is fed and happy and 
productive, there are no real looming threats to humanity, and the people 
who run the world are totally qualified because they were bred specifically 
for that role. It's only scary because we're accustomed to something else 
and are more aware than the average citizen, taking the ignorance is 
bliss thing to a recognizable level instead of just a saying. It's 
everything we strive to achieve on a day to day basis, but actually 
achieved. And when considering other dystopian universes, BNW's is amongst 
the better ones by a longshot.
comments.author: mclovinakapascal

comments.text:
I always thought it fell into the anti-Utopian subgenre, as a critique

comments.text:
And here I was hoping I'd get a proper translation of those compliments 
directed towards the women of the story as "pneumatic." I've read this book 
3 years ago as a book project for my English class. At the time the, only 
definition I got was that it meant something filled with air, so I thought 
they were thinking of the girls as blow up sex dolls. BUUTTTT

A quick google check right now tells me that pneumatic(as a compliment to 
women)= big tits. Example (as given by google) "Lee and his *pneumatic wife*" 
so yeah...go have fun with that word. There's finally a single word to 
describe big titties that was actually used so many many years ago. 
Grandpas must have told grandmas all over of how pneumatic they are...

Well anyway, thank you Thug Notes for that wonderful analysis. Now 
everything makes sense to me. I didn't know about that religion/opium quote 
so I can finally see what went wrong for that poor savage guy.﻿
comments.author: White Asylum
